subject: Graceful shutdown WSGI server
commit_message:
Graceful shutdown WSGI server

Currently, termination of WSGI application immediately stops service and so
interrupts in-progress request. This could cause problem when do upgrading.

Following related things were done:
1. Removed signal handler for SIGINT to allow instantaneous shutdown.
2. Call launcher.stop() was moved from _child_wait_for_exit_or_signal method
to SIGTERM signal handler and pipe_watcher method because service must not be
stopped for example if SIGHUP comes.
3. Added stop server operation before sending TERM signal to children
processes to close listening socket in master process. Because if socket in
master process is opened, user could successfully connects to API server but
without receiving response.
4. On children side before calling _exit() added call launcher.wait() to allow
gracefully shutdown on SIGTERM.
5. Removed service.wait() from Services.stop() to make it not-blocking call.
6. Removed stop-start operations from Services.restart method because of two
reasons:
  - why stop/start service if we have reset() service's method;

subject: Database changes for conductor horizontal scale
commit_message:
Database changes for conductor horizontal scale

Add database APIs for a conductor to lock/steal/release a bay.
There will be more than one conductors, so it is necessary to
implement a distributed locking APIs to prevent race conditions.

* Lock acquisition: A conductor should acquire a lock when it is
  about to perform an operation on a bay (e.g. create/update/delete
  a bay). The conductor should check the return value of the APIs
  to determine if the lock is successfully acquired. If yes, another
  conductor that attempts to lock the same bay will not succeed.
  Upon completion, the conductor should release the acquired lock to
  allow other conductors to operate the bay later.
* Lock stealing: If conductor A acquires a lock and crashes
  unexpectedly, conductor B can steal the lock acquired by
  conductor A. To do that, conductor B needs to give the id of
  conductor A along with other parameters. The lock stealing will
  succeed if the bay is indeed locked by conductor A at the moment
  of the stealing requests.

subject: Allow specifying project branch in redstack
commit_message:
Allow specifying project branch in redstack

At present, redstack clones the most recent version of devstack and
each project.  Sometimes this is undesirable as these repositories can
become unstable.  A solution to this would be to add an environment
variable or option to redstack to specify the branch or commit to use
(with the default remaining 'master').

With this change you can now specify scenarios like:

- To switch all projects (including devstack) to a stable branch:
PROJECT_BRANCH=stable/kilo ./redstack install

- To switch all projects to a stable branch, but have a specific
  devstack commit used:
PROJECT_BRANCH=stable/kilo DEVSTACK_BRANCH=7ef2464 ./redstack install

- To switch all projects (including devstack) to a stable branch,
but have a specific commit for Nova:
PROJECT_BRANCH=stable/kilo NOVA_BRANCH=7ef2464 ./redstack install

- To switch all projects to a stable branch, but have a different
stable branch for the clients:
PROJECT_BRANCH=stable/juno PROJECT_CLIENT_BRANCH=stable/kilo ...

Redstack would then switch to the corresponding branches/commits
before running './stack.sh'

Optionally, for persistence, these variables can be defined in either
options.rc or ~/.redstack.options.rc

The repos are switched, even if the project directories already existed.

If an invalid branch/commit is specified, redstack stops with an error
message.

The following environment variables are now supported (in order of
precedence):
<PROJECT>_BRANCH - where <PROJECT> is either DEVSTACK or is defined
                   in *projects-list
                   i.e. NOVA_BRANCH, CINDER_BRANCH, DEVSTACK_BRANCH
PROJECT_CLIENT_BRANCH
PROJECT_BRANCH

Note: Setting PROJECT_BRANCH or PROJECT_CLIENT_BRANCH will *not*
affect the Trove project - you must use TROVE_BRANCH and
PYTHON_TROVECLIENT specifically for that.

Change-Id: I50c64db917bb87bac5d1b1d4d0231270577e26a8
Closes-Bug: #1449627

subject: compute: stop handling virt lifecycle events in cleanup_host()
commit_message:
compute: stop handling virt lifecycle events in cleanup_host()

When rebooting a compute host, guest VMs can be getting shutdown
automatically by the hypervisor and the virt driver is sending events to
the compute manager to handle them. If the compute service is still up
while this happens it will try to call the stop API to power off the
instance and update the database to show the instance as stopped.

When the compute service comes back up and events come in from the virt
driver that the guest VMs are running, nova will see that the vm_state
on the instance in the nova database is STOPPED and shut down the
instance by calling the stop API (basically ignoring what the virt
driver / hypervisor tells nova is the state of the guest VM).

Alternatively, if the compute service shuts down after changing the
intance task_state to 'powering-off' but before the stop API cast is
complete, the instance can be in a strange vm_state/task_state
combination that requires the admin to manually reset the task_state to
recover the instance.

Let's just try to avoid some of this mess by disconnecting the event
handling when the compute service is shutting down like we do for
neutron VIF plugging events. There could still be races here if the
compute service is shutting down after the hypervisor (e.g. libvirtd),
but this is at least a best attempt to do the mitigate the potential
damage.

Closes-Bug: #1444630
Related-Bug: #1293480
Related-Bug: #1408176

Conflicts:
	nova/compute/manager.py
	nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py

The Default Neutron implementation needs a router with a gateway to associate a
FIP. So by default a topology check will be performed by horizon to list only

(e.g.: OpenContrail) owned by a tenant.

This patch adds a setting allowing to bypass the topology check in order to let
the user associate a FIP to an instance on a subnet with no router if the
Neutron backend allows it.

subject: Remove NO_SIGNAL from puppet role templates
commit_message:
Remove NO_SIGNAL from puppet role templates

Currently we use NO_SIGNAL on both the NetworkConfig and subsequent config
deploying the data associated with the role.  This means there is a risk that
should the NetworkConfig do anything interruptive (os-net-config can do
interface renaming based on discovery data for example) the role configuration
config could fail, and we'd never know until some later error occurs.

Additionally, we need to be sure that the heiradata deployed by each of the role
specicific configs is actually in-place before proceeding with any of the cluster
configuration - atm this works due to the inherent delays involved deploying to
bare-metal, but there's still a theoretical race if very fast deployment backends
(I'm thinking containers, e.g lxc backend to nova or something) were used instead.

Essentially, we should never be using NO_SIGNAL unless we want to ignore failure,
which AFAICT is not the case in this instance.

subject: Allow control of hostname formatting
commit_message:
Allow control of hostname formatting

Currently, we use the heat default server names, which results in some
fairly unreadable hostnames due to the level of nesting in the templates.

e.g ov-sszdbj5rdne-0-bhseh65edxv6-Controller-zoqc6tlypbdp

Instead, we allow the user to specify a format string per role, defaulted
to a string which formats the name e.g <stackname>-controller-<index>

e.g overcloud-controller-0

Optionally additional hostname components (not replaced by heat) could be
added, such that deployment time customization of hostnames via firstboot
scripts (e.g cloud-init) may be possible.

Should anyone wish to maintain the old heat-generated names, they can pass
an empty string via these parameters, which heat will treat as if no "name"
property was provided to OS::Nova::Server.

subject: mirror/centos: fail on broken/missing package(s)
commit_message:
mirror/centos: fail on broken/missing package(s)

Apparently yumdownloader does not raise an error if some packages are
missing or broken (dependencies can not be satisfied). As a result some
packages have silently disappered from the mirror (kmod-openvswitch) and
others have been broken (sheepdog).

Patch yumdownloader so it bails out if some packages are missing or have
broken dependencies. As a side effect yumdownloader raises an error if
some of the packages being downloaded conflict (like kernel-headers vs
kernel-headers-lt), so modify the mirroring code to detect and handle
the conflicting packages.

More strict dependencies check yield some unexpected issues. In
particular a few 32 bit packages are broken due to the upgraded base
packages from Fuel repo being x86_64 only. In particular, 32 bit dmraid
package is broken due to device-mapper-libs:

Package: device-mapper-libs-1.02.79-8.el6.i686 (base)
    Requires: device-mapper = 1.02.79-8.el6
    Available: device-mapper-1.02.79-8.el6.x86_64 (base)
        device-mapper = 1.02.79-8.el6
    Installing: device-mapper-1.02.90-2.mira1.x86_64 (fuel)
        device-mapper = 1.02.90-2.mira1

To solve the problem configure yum to exclude most of i686 packages.
The configuration appeared to be a bit cumbersome since *some* i686
packages are required. In particular syslinux package requires
syslinux-nonlinux (binaries which run in syslinux environment before
booting the OS) which is formally an i686 package.

Closes-Bug: #1457382
